THE NEWS -LETTER.

Single students can make their names immortal by giving pictures, curtains, and all the
other things that make a room look cheerful
and hospitable. Each class can add to the wall
decorations its shield in shape of an enlarged
class pin.
Some men may contend that the ornaments
would be broken in the course of pot socials or
class fights. The wise and far-seeing faculty
prevents all damages by forbidding any kind of
class rush, fighting or boxing under the roof
of the gymnasium.
HOPKINS AND HARVARD.
In the columns of THE NEWS-LETTER several articles have appeared offering various
suggestions for the promotion of college spirit
and mutual fellowship among the students at
the University. However admirable these suggestions may be, they will surely prove useless
unless they fall upon fruitful soil. All of us are
aware of a certain diffidence on the part of
Hopkins men, whenever a comparison is
drawn between their own institution and the
large and wealthy colleges of the North. Of
course, they are proud of the position occupied
by Johns Hopkins in the field of learning; but
as soon as the conversation turns upon those
qualities that go to make up a college in the
popular sense, they assume an apologetic attitude. Until this distrust has been removed,
we cannot execute with any zest the schemes
for improving our athletic standing and advancing the interests of the University by
other means, and the best way to remove it is
to show that it is unwarranted by the facts.
Let us take Harvard as an example. It is
the largest, the oldest, the wealthiest of American universities ; it has more students in a
single class than the Hopkins in all its departments ; it has a beautiful campus and magnificent dormitories; and yet most Hopkins men
would be surprised to see in how many respects it is inferior as a college to their own
Alma Mater.
The chronic state of affairs
among the students at Cambridge is what a
writer in Scribner's has termed "Harvard indifference." "If the football team has been
beaten, we are sorry, to be sure ; but, after all,

the loss falls upon the University, and not
upon us "—that is the sentiment which their
actions and sometimes their words express.
This fact is easily accounted for by the immense size of the institution, by the complicated system of social clubs, with its "inner
circles" and wheels within wheels, and perhaps by a certain Northern stolidity of temperament. The important point for us is that
none of these causes exists or is every likely to
exist at the Johns Hopkins.
If, then, this is the condition which prevails
at so old and celebrated a college as Harvard,
can we not disabuse our minds of the notion,
fostered by Yankee school teachers, that, in
comparison with our larger rivals, the Hopkins has no college spirit ? Doubtless, we
have still much room for improvement; but
we are far better, relatively speaking, than we
have been artfully led to believe.
ARTHUR W. MACHEN, JR.
THE PASSING OF THE YEAR.
I.

Twilight—
Of the darkening firelight ;
Silence — thickening with the thickening
gloom.
Revery—
Giving soul to every
Flickering shadow in the dusky room.
Jarring—
Its way through hush-clouds, warring—
A sound bursts forth—for heavy the charring
log has sunk.
And elate
O'er their victim prostrate
The fire-worms madly gnaw along its trunk.
Flaring,
A thin blue flame, despairing,
Leaps from the log; and upward and away
Has darted.
And so—their soul departed—
Gather the ashes up, all cold and gray—
Cast them away.

NEWS OF A FORTNIGHT.
THE PUBLIC DEBATE AT EASTER.
At the meeting of the House of Representatives Wednesday, January 5, Mr. Censor announced that there would be a public debate
at Easter between the classes of '98 and '99.
"Dr. Adams," he said, "has kindly given, as
prizes for the contest, three gold medals and a
trophy, in the form of a mahogany tablet, with
Silver trimmings." A vote of thanks was extended by the House to Dr. Adams for his
munificent gifts. The House voted that there
Should be nine men to represent the class in
this debate. Six, who will be regulars or alternates, will be chosen by the Censor, purely on
their merits, and three, who are to act as advisers, will be elected by the House. The
names of all nine, if they are successful, will be
engraved on the trophy, which is to be placed
in the Donovan Room, McCoy Hall. The
question which is to be debated at Easter will
be debated three times in the House, to insure
a clear interpretation and forcible presentation of the subject.
The impeachment of Mr. Kaufman created
quite a stir in the House. The charges are,
briefly, that Mr. Kaufman is, as a freshman,
not eligible to attend the meetings of the
House; that he has not the consent of the
Censor, which would enable him to attend.
The attorneys appointed for the defense are
Congressmen Fisher, Guggenheimer and
Ross ; for the prosecution, Congressmen Mullen and Grimes. The trial, which will take
Place at the next meeting of the House, will
be open to members of other classes, only by
special permission of the Censor.
The regular debate proved interesting, and
was debated with considerable zeal and dexterity. The question was : "Resolved, That
capital punishment ought to be abolished."
The affirmative was taken by Congressmen
R emsen and Keidel ; the negative by Congressmen Krager, Murkland and Davinson.
The negative side, by their better presentation,
won the debate. The affirmative side was,
however, somewhat handicapped by the absence of one of their number.

THE AMERICAN HISTORICAL ASSOCIATION.
The American Historical Association held
its thirteenth annual convention in Cleveland
during the Christmas holidays. A number of
Hopkins men attended. Out of 35 different
announcements of papers on the programme,
no less than 14. were by representatives, past
and present, of the Johns Hopkins University.
Recent graduates of the University, who had
a place on the Cleveland programme were Dr.
J. M. Callahan, who this month assumes the
duties of Historical Professor at Hamilton
College, Clinton, N. Y.; Dr. Franklin L. Riley,
who has lately become Professor of History in
the University of Mississippi; and Doctors B.
C. Steiner, J. C. Ballagh, and John H. Latane,
now resident in Baltimore.
The Association now numbers about one
thousand picked members, all chosen on nomination by existing members. There are over
one hundred life members. Among these are
President McKinley and ex-President Cleveland. The chosen President for the current
year is George P. Fisher, of Yale University.
Dr. James Schouler, of the Johns Hopkins
University, retires from the Presidency of the
Association into the Executive Council for
life. Chief Justice Fuller, already a member
of the Association and a regent of the Smithsonian Institution, was elected a member of
the Executive Council. The next meeting
will be held in the new building of the New
Haven Historical Society during the Christmas holidays of the current year.
Professor Moore, instructor here in economics for the year 1896-'97, and now Professor at Smith College, is delivering a course of
twelve lectures on the "Mathematical Methods
in Economics" at the Hopkins. Professor
Moore was one of the most popular of the
younger instructors while at the Hopkins, and
his resignation was a source of universal regret, though his call to fill a very prominent
chair at Smith afforded a pleasing instance of
his popularity and showed his recognized
ability.

A petition has recently appeared which recites the difficulties heretofore met with in the
equipment of teams, and the raising of guarantees, and seeks to provide a remedy. The
trustees are asked to charge a locker rent of
five dollars, to prohibit the use of the gymnasium and cage to all who do not rent lockers, and to devote the money so raised to the
needy cause of team athletics. This is a wellmeant, but misguided, effort. The possibility
that the trustees would grant such a petition,
even if it were generally signed, seems very
remote.
It rests upon a complete misconception of
the purpose of college athletics. The gymnasium is designed to give to students, whose
lives are sedentary, the exercise necessary to
good health. Inter-collegiate sport is a legitimate, hut by no means essential, outgrowth
of this principle. It would be unreasonable
and unjust to enforce from a student who
chooses to confine his exercise to chestweights and clubs, a contribution to the expenses of the teams. The lockers should be
free, and every encouragement should be offered to the use of the gymnasium and cage.

President Gilman.has presented his twentysecond annual report, of which we can only say,
read it. Many students have but vague ideas
of the work which is being done at this University. Often they are those very ones who
are always crying out on the lack of college
spirit. College spirit is a word which, we believe has never been defined, and which is accompanied by conceptions in different minds.
For some men it is merely a form of rowdyism,
for others, athletic enthusiasm, for many both
of these. Again, the different forms of class
feeling are by many believed to constitute the
essence of college spirit. To us it seems that
loyalty to the University in all of its phases is
true college spirit. Uphold the honor of your
Alma Mater in all possible ways, spread her
fame wherever you may live, at present or in
the future. This can be well done only by men
who know of the work accomplished in all the
departments, and the quickest way of gaining
this knowledge consists in reading over such
publications as the President's report.
THE NEWS-LETTER remarks a growing anxiety among certain seniors lest those good old
clays when the "pot social" was in our midst
(or we in its) may have already gone into history, and taken with them, also, those rejuvenating times when juniors, in spite of freshmen,
and freshmen on the sly, got together to make
a joyful noise about the board, under the special inspiration of a clever deduction of Vinunt
vos liberabit from the University motto and the
generally accepted proverb, In vino veritas.
Is there any ground for this anxiety? Have
freshmen and juniors at last succumbed to the
omni-stifling power of respectability ? Will
no more gallant youths make "hairbreadth
'scapes i' the imminent deadly breach" of a
car window, or boldly scour the country 'round
in search of some windmill to attack? 'Tis
pity ! We must have some little excitement
to break the dull monotony of the knowledgesyphous ceaseless flow. The sight of red-

we owe to our University in return for the
benefits she bestows on us is to prove ourselves in all respects her worthy representatives. Yet the men here persistently neglect
the one thing which will both improve themselves physically and at the same time add to
Hopkins' reputation.
Perhaps it may be said that Hopkins needs
no athletic standing. True, we might not be
seriously injured as a College by the loss of
our teams, though the loss to the individual
men would be great.
But there is a consideration more important
than that. In fact, the johns Hopkins does
place teams on the field every year, and it is a
woeful fact that we have to submit to defeat
at the hands of second-rate colleges. This
should move every student to make all possible efforts for the improvement of our athletic standard.

A GRADUATE STUDENT.
The class of 'goo held A meeting Wednesday, January 5. The class elected Carroll
Wight captain of the indoor baseball team,
with the authority to choose a manager. Roland Abercrombie was elected member of the
House Committee of the new gymnasium.
The meeting was well attended.

A GRADUATE ON GRADUATES.

There seems to be an idea among the graduate students of the Hopkins that they have
no part in the affairs of the College in general.
There was never a greater mistake. Graduates, as well as undergraduates, should, as
students of the Hopkins, lend aid to everything which concerns our College. Why
should graduate students who are here to
enjoy the splendid advantages offered by the
University feel that it is not their duty to do
what they can to advance her interests ? This
we fail in many ways to do probably most
noticeably in the line of athletics. To be sure,
this is not the main end of a graduate student's
existence, Other things should, as they do,
claim our first attention. But anyone must
admit the value of a trained body, such as is
gained through outdoor sports, and the least

THE NEWS-LETTER.
ATHLETICS.
GYMNASTICS AND ATHLETICS.

On the 31st of December, 1897, there met at
the Knickerbocker Club in New York, the directors of the gymnasiums of many of the
larger colleges and universities.
A preliminary meeting had been held on
Nov. 6, and invitations issued to the principal
colleges and universities in the country to send
representatives on the above date. Almost all
sent letters expressing a thorough sympathy
with, and great interest in, the meeting. It was
sufficient, however, that the pioneers in this
work, Dr. Dudley A. Sargent, of Harvard; Dr.
Edward Hitchcock, of Amherst; Dr. W. G.
Anderson, of Yale; and men from colleges
which are following in the footsteps of these institutions were present.
The object of this meeting was to organize
an association to be known as the "Society for
the Advancement of Physical Culture in Colleges." For some time past gymnasium directors have felt that the "American Association
for the Advancement of Physical Education,"
covered too broad a field and was not giving
them just what they needed, and what they expected. To fill this much-felt requirement, the
"Society for the Advancement of Physical
Culture in Colleges" had been organized. The
men who compose it, must be members of the
parent organization and no gymnasium in,structor can become a member who has not
followed gymnastics as a profession for at least
two years. The new society will concern itself
with gymnasium work alone, and thus directors will be brought closer together, methods
will be criticised, and, best of all, a common
standard will be adopted and arrived at by all.
A constitution and by-laws were adopted,
under which Dr. Jay Seaver, of Yale, was elected President; Dr. Watson Savage, of Columbia, Secretary-Treasurer. These officers, with
Dr. Sargent, of Harvard, and Prof. Cann, New
York University, will constitute the council, or
managing board.
Two papers were read—one by Dr. Anderson, on "Terminology," the other by Dr. Sar-

gent on "Strength Tests." Dr. Sargent, who
was chairman of the committee appointed at
the first meeting, read a report which, after
considerable discussion, was adopted by the society. This report -adopts the following
strength tests:
r. Strength of right and left hands.
2. Strength of back.
3. Strength of legs.
4. Strength of lungs.
5. Strength of biceps and triceps, as shown
by the number of times a person can pull up
on a horizontal bar, and push up on the parallel
bars. These two, added together, multiplied
by his weight in kilos and divided by ten is considered the strength of the chest and arms. Instead of strength of lungs. As no machine for
testing the lung strength has been found at all
satisfactory so far, one twentieth of lung capacity will be generally used.
These measurements have all been taken at
Hopkins University since the gymnasium was
first built. The main point of interest to gymnasium directors and to students is that Dr.
Sargent and the Faculty of Harvard have enforced a certain standard of strength based in
these tests as a condition of playing on teams.
Thus in. order to play on a football team, or
row in a boat crew, or contest in heavyweight
throwing, a student must show a total
strength test of 700 or over. In order to play
lacrosse or baseball, he must reach 600 or over,
and for track athletics, 500 or over. The directors who were present were asked to work on
this basis in their colleges, and all agreed to do
so. When a student falls below these requirements he is debarred from a team, and no
amount of favoritism can put him on instead of
a man who has come up to the standard. The
only thing for him to do then, is to work in the
gymnasium and bring his strength up to standard. In order to create interest in the "strong
man" the Society will offer a banner or medal
to the highest or greatest "total strength" made
by any one in the colleges. As an incentive to
our students, 1, Mr. Editor, will offer a prize to
be competed for by the three classes.
In your next edition, Mr. Editor, if you will

grant me space, I hope to present from my records the strength tests of some of the best
teams in the history of the University.
J. B. CRENSHAW,

characterized by a lack of team work, and
slugging was frequent on both sides.
In the first half the puck was batted back
and forth from one end of the rink to the other, and neither side was able to score.
Throughout this half Walbrook showed a tendency to fall on the puck when it came near the
goal, at one time as many as three men going
down at once, Hodges' head was cut by the
puck.
. In the second half the puck stayed in Walbrook's territory most of the time, only going
once or twice near Hopkins goal, and giving
Scholl a chance to make a couple of brilliant
stops. Toward the end of the half Hopkins
managed to use a little team work, and in the
last five minutes of play McInnes and Hodges
each made a goal for Hopkins.
In the second half Wilson, Walbrook's
point, sprained his ankle and Turner took his
place. Purnell put up the best game for Walbrook, but had a bad way of running over the
puck; in fact both teams found it very hard
not to leave the puck behind, in their haste to
score. The defense was good on both teams,
and Scholl in particular put up a great game.
Hodges and McInnes did best for Hopkins
on the attack.
The previous game with Walbrook, Dec. 21,
also resulted in a victory for Hopkins, the
score being 3 to 1. Hopkins is now tied for

THE NEWS-LETTER.
DR. BAKER ON 11UNIC1I.

Munich was the subject of an address delivered by Dr. Baker of the Modern Language
Department before the Historical and Political
Science Association last Friday evening. Dr.
Baker considers Munich the greatest art centre
in the world, easily outstripping Berlin, and
probably even Paris. The growing supremacy
of Berlin in art is due partly to Emperor William's imperious interference in such matters in
Berlin, and partly to the impetus given to art
by the romantic and deeply lamented Ludwig.
To say that a city is in Germany is equivalent
to saying that it is well governed. Munich is
no exception to this rule, and the business
methods by which the internal government of
the city are managed are a source of pride to
its inhabitants. The Mayors serve their apprenticeships, as it were, in smaller towns and
cities before they are called to the control of
affairs in Munich.
Business activity in Munich is noticeably absent. Almost the only signs of a brisk commercial life are shown by the one hundred
breweries, which are taxed to their uttermost
to provide for the proverbial Teutonic thirst
for "Das Bier."
The two features of Munich, which make
usually the most impression upon foreigners,
are the prevalence of cafe life and the numbers
of princes and implied connection between
these is not necessarily inferred, yet they manage to exist very harmoniously together.
Princes may be seen of all grades, classes and
conditions.
The cafes constitute the principal "rendezvous" for all classes. One of the most perplexing questions for an unsophisticated American
is to know what title to use in addressing a native. It is a mortal offense to employ anything
else than a person's highest title. A man's title
is always used in addressing his frau.
At the conclusion of the address Mr. Renouf, of the class of '98, and the editorial staff
of the NEWS LETTER made a short talk based
upon personal reminiscences of a long residence in Munich. Mr. Renouf spoke df the
German fondness for Sunday picnics and ex-

cursions. Whole families together go out in
the country for several miles, and spend the
day wandering around and climbing mountains, and while occupied in the latter pursuit
quite a number fall and break their necks,
"which pastime," Mr. Renouf curiously remarked, "they enjoyed very much."

THE NEWS -LETTER.

Single students can make their names immortal by giving pictures, curtains, and all the
other things that make a room look cheerful
and hospitable. Each class can add to the wall
decorations its shield in shape of an enlarged
class pin.
Some men may contend that the ornaments
would be broken in the course of pot socials or
class fights. The wise and far-seeing faculty
prevents all damages by forbidding any kind of
class rush, fighting or boxing under the roof
of the gymnasium.
HOPKINS AND HARVARD.
In the columns of THE NEWS-LETTER several articles have appeared offering various
suggestions for the promotion of college spirit
and mutual fellowship among the students at
the University. However admirable these suggestions may be, they will surely prove useless
unless they fall upon fruitful soil. All of us are
aware of a certain diffidence on the part of
Hopkins men, whenever a comparison is
drawn between their own institution and the
large and wealthy colleges of the North. Of
course, they are proud of the position occupied
by Johns Hopkins in the field of learning; but
as soon as the conversation turns upon those
qualities that go to make up a college in the
popular sense, they assume an apologetic attitude. Until this distrust has been removed,
we cannot execute with any zest the schemes
for improving our athletic standing and advancing the interests of the University by
other means, and the best way to remove it is
to show that it is unwarranted by the facts.
Let us take Harvard as an example. It is
the largest, the oldest, the wealthiest of American universities ; it has more students in a
single class than the Hopkins in all its departments ; it has a beautiful campus and magnificent dormitories; and yet most Hopkins men
would be surprised to see in how many respects it is inferior as a college to their own
Alma Mater.
The chronic state of affairs
among the students at Cambridge is what a
writer in Scribner's has termed "Harvard indifference." "If the football team has been
beaten, we are sorry, to be sure ; but, after all,

the loss falls upon the University, and not
upon us "—that is the sentiment which their
actions and sometimes their words express.
This fact is easily accounted for by the immense size of the institution, by the complicated system of social clubs, with its "inner
circles" and wheels within wheels, and perhaps by a certain Northern stolidity of temperament. The important point for us is that
none of these causes exists or is every likely to
exist at the Johns Hopkins.
If, then, this is the condition which prevails
at so old and celebrated a college as Harvard,
can we not disabuse our minds of the notion,
fostered by Yankee school teachers, that, in
comparison with our larger rivals, the Hopkins has no college spirit ? Doubtless, we
have still much room for improvement; but
we are far better, relatively speaking, than we
have been artfully led to believe.
ARTHUR W. MACHEN, JR.
THE PASSING OF THE YEAR.
I.

Twilight—
Of the darkening firelight ;
Silence — thickening with the thickening
gloom.
Revery—
Giving soul to every
Flickering shadow in the dusky room.
Jarring—
Its way through hush-clouds, warring—
A sound bursts forth—for heavy the charring
log has sunk.
And elate
O'er their victim prostrate
The fire-worms madly gnaw along its trunk.
Flaring,
A thin blue flame, despairing,
Leaps from the log; and upward and away

NEWS OF A FORTNIGHT.
THE PUBLIC DEBATE AT EASTER.
At the meeting of the House of Representatives Wednesday, January 5, Mr. Censor announced that there would be a public debate
at Easter between the classes of '98 and '99.
"Dr. Adams," he said, "has kindly given, as
prizes for the contest, three gold medals and a
trophy, in the form of a mahogany tablet, with
Silver trimmings." A vote of thanks was extended by the House to Dr. Adams for his
munificent gifts. The House voted that there
Should be nine men to represent the class in
this debate. Six, who will be regulars or alternates, will be chosen by the Censor, purely on
their merits, and three, who are to act as advisers, will be elected by the House. The
names of all nine, if they are successful, will be
engraved on the trophy, which is to be placed
in the Donovan Room, McCoy Hall. The
question which is to be debated at Easter will
be debated three times in the House, to insure
a clear interpretation and forcible presentation of the subject.
The impeachment of Mr. Kaufman created
quite a stir in the House. The charges are,
briefly, that Mr. Kaufman is, as a freshman,
not eligible to attend the meetings of the
House; that he has not the consent of the
Censor, which would enable him to attend.
The attorneys appointed for the defense are
Congressmen Fisher, Guggenheimer and
Ross ; for the prosecution, Congressmen Mullen and Grimes. The trial, which will take
Place at the next meeting of the House, will
be open to members of other classes, only by
special permission of the Censor.
The regular debate proved interesting, and
was debated with considerable zeal and dexterity. The question was : "Resolved, That
capital punishment ought to be abolished."
The affirmative was taken by Congressmen
R emsen and Keidel ; the negative by Congressmen Krager, Murkland and Davinson.
The negative side, by their better presentation,
won the debate. The affirmative side was,
however, somewhat handicapped by the absence of one of their number.

THE AMERICAN HISTORICAL ASSOCIATION.
The American Historical Association held
its thirteenth annual convention in Cleveland
during the Christmas holidays. A number of
Hopkins men attended. Out of 35 different
announcements of papers on the programme,
no less than 14. were by representatives, past
and present, of the Johns Hopkins University.
Recent graduates of the University, who had
a place on the Cleveland programme were Dr.
J. M. Callahan, who this month assumes the
duties of Historical Professor at Hamilton
College, Clinton, N. Y.; Dr. Franklin L. Riley,
who has lately become Professor of History in
the University of Mississippi; and Doctors B.
C. Steiner, J. C. Ballagh, and John H. Latane,
now resident in Baltimore.
The Association now numbers about one
thousand picked members, all chosen on nomination by existing members. There are over
one hundred life members. Among these are
President McKinley and ex-President Cleveland. The chosen President for the current
year is George P. Fisher, of Yale University.
Dr. James Schouler, of the Johns Hopkins
University, retires from the Presidency of the
Association into the Executive Council for
life. Chief Justice Fuller, already a member
of the Association and a regent of the Smithsonian Institution, was elected a member of
the Executive Council. The next meeting
will be held in the new building of the New
Haven Historical Society during the Christmas holidays of the current year.
Professor Moore, instructor here in economics for the year 1896-'97, and now Professor at Smith College, is delivering a course of
twelve lectures on the "Mathematical Methods
in Economics" at the Hopkins. Professor
Moore was one of the most popular of the
younger instructors while at the Hopkins, and
his resignation was a source of universal regret, though his call to fill a very prominent
chair at Smith afforded a pleasing instance of
his popularity and showed his recognized
ability.

A petition has recently appeared which recites the difficulties heretofore met with in the
equipment of teams, and the raising of guarantees, and seeks to provide a remedy. The
trustees are asked to charge a locker rent of
five dollars, to prohibit the use of the gymnasium and cage to all who do not rent lockers, and to devote the money so raised to the
needy cause of team athletics. This is a wellmeant, but misguided, effort. The possibility
that the trustees would grant such a petition,
even if it were generally signed, seems very
remote.
It rests upon a complete misconception of
the purpose of college athletics. The gymnasium is designed to give to students, whose
lives are sedentary, the exercise necessary to
good health. Inter-collegiate sport is a legitimate, hut by no means essential, outgrowth
of this principle. It would be unreasonable
and unjust to enforce from a student who
chooses to confine his exercise to chestweights and clubs, a contribution to the expenses of the teams. The lockers should be
free, and every encouragement should be offered to the use of the gymnasium and cage.

President Gilman.has presented his twentysecond annual report, of which we can only say,
read it. Many students have but vague ideas
of the work which is being done at this University. Often they are those very ones who
are always crying out on the lack of college
spirit. College spirit is a word which, we believe has never been defined, and which is accompanied by conceptions in different minds.
For some men it is merely a form of rowdyism,
for others, athletic enthusiasm, for many both
of these. Again, the different forms of class
feeling are by many believed to constitute the
essence of college spirit. To us it seems that
loyalty to the University in all of its phases is
true college spirit. Uphold the honor of your
Alma Mater in all possible ways, spread her
fame wherever you may live, at present or in
the future. This can be well done only by men
who know of the work accomplished in all the
departments, and the quickest way of gaining
this knowledge consists in reading over such
publications as the President's report.

A GRADUATE ON GRADUATES.

There seems to be an idea among the graduate students of the Hopkins that they have
no part in the affairs of the College in general.
There was never a greater mistake. Graduates, as well as undergraduates, should, as

admit the value of a trained body, such as is

THE NEWS-LETTER.
ATHLETICS.
GYMNASTICS AND ATHLETICS.

On the 31st of December, 1897, there met at
the Knickerbocker Club in New York, the directors of the gymnasiums of many of the
larger colleges and universities.
A preliminary meeting had been held on
Nov. 6, and invitations issued to the principal
colleges and universities in the country to send
representatives on the above date. Almost all
sent letters expressing a thorough sympathy
with, and great interest in, the meeting. It was
sufficient, however, that the pioneers in this
work, Dr. Dudley A. Sargent, of Harvard; Dr.
Edward Hitchcock, of Amherst; Dr. W. G.
Anderson, of Yale; and men from colleges
which are following in the footsteps of these institutions were present.
The object of this meeting was to organize
an association to be known as the "Society for
the Advancement of Physical Culture in Colleges." For some time past gymnasium directors have felt that the "American Association
for the Advancement of Physical Education,"
covered too broad a field and was not giving
them just what they needed, and what they expected. To fill this much-felt requirement, the
"Society for the Advancement of Physical
Culture in Colleges" had been organized. The
men who compose it, must be members of the
parent organization and no gymnasium in,structor can become a member who has not
followed gymnastics as a profession for at least
two years. The new society will concern itself
with gymnasium work alone, and thus directors will be brought closer together, methods
will be criticised, and, best of all, a common
standard will be adopted and arrived at by all.
A constitution and by-laws were adopted,
under which Dr. Jay Seaver, of Yale, was elected President; Dr. Watson Savage, of Columbia, Secretary-Treasurer. These officers, with
Dr. Sargent, of Harvard, and Prof. Cann, New
York University, will constitute the council, or
managing board.
Two papers were read—one by Dr. Anderson, on "Terminology," the other by Dr. Sar-

gent on "Strength Tests." Dr. Sargent, who
was chairman of the committee appointed at
the first meeting, read a report which, after
considerable discussion, was adopted by the society. This report -adopts the following
strength tests:
r. Strength of right and left hands.
2. Strength of back.
3. Strength of legs.
4. Strength of lungs.
5. Strength of biceps and triceps, as shown
by the number of times a person can pull up
on a horizontal bar, and push up on the parallel
bars. These two, added together, multiplied
by his weight in kilos and divided by ten is considered the strength of the chest and arms. Instead of strength of lungs. As no machine for
testing the lung strength has been found at all
satisfactory so far, one twentieth of lung capacity will be generally used.
These measurements have all been taken at
Hopkins University since the gymnasium was
first built. The main point of interest to gymnasium directors and to students is that Dr.
Sargent and the Faculty of Harvard have enforced a certain standard of strength based in
these tests as a condition of playing on teams.
Thus in. order to play on a football team, or
row in a boat crew, or contest in heavyweight
throwing, a student must show a total
strength test of 700 or over. In order to play
lacrosse or baseball, he must reach 600 or over,
and for track athletics, 500 or over. The directors who were present were asked to work on
this basis in their colleges, and all agreed to do
so. When a student falls below these requirements he is debarred from a team, and no
amount of favoritism can put him on instead of
a man who has come up to the standard. The
only thing for him to do then, is to work in the
gymnasium and bring his strength up to standard. In order to create interest in the "strong
man" the Society will offer a banner or medal
to the highest or greatest "total strength" made
by any one in the colleges. As an incentive to
our students, 1, Mr. Editor, will offer a prize to
be competed for by the three classes.
In your next edition, Mr. Editor, if you will

THE NEWS-LETTER.
DR. BAKER ON 11UNIC1I.

Munich was the subject of an address delivered by Dr. Baker of the Modern Language
Department before the Historical and Political
Science Association last Friday evening. Dr.
Baker considers Munich the greatest art centre
in the world, easily outstripping Berlin, and
probably even Paris. The growing supremacy
of Berlin in art is due partly to Emperor William's imperious interference in such matters in
Berlin, and partly to the impetus given to art
by the romantic and deeply lamented Ludwig.
To say that a city is in Germany is equivalent
to saying that it is well governed. Munich is
no exception to this rule, and the business
methods by which the internal government of
the city are managed are a source of pride to
its inhabitants. The Mayors serve their apprenticeships, as it were, in smaller towns and
cities before they are called to the control of
affairs in Munich.
Business activity in Munich is noticeably absent. Almost the only signs of a brisk commercial life are shown by the one hundred
breweries, which are taxed to their uttermost
to provide for the proverbial Teutonic thirst
for "Das Bier."
The two features of Munich, which make
usually the most impression upon foreigners,
are the prevalence of cafe life and the numbers
of princes and implied connection between
these is not necessarily inferred, yet they manage to exist very harmoniously together.
Princes may be seen of all grades, classes and
conditions.
The cafes constitute the principal "rendezvous" for all classes. One of the most perplexing questions for an unsophisticated American
is to know what title to use in addressing a native. It is a mortal offense to employ anything
else than a person's highest title. A man's title
is always used in addressing his frau.
At the conclusion of the address Mr. Renouf, of the class of '98, and the editorial staff
of the NEWS LETTER made a short talk based
upon personal reminiscences of a long residence in Munich. Mr. Renouf spoke df the
German fondness for Sunday picnics and ex-

cursions. Whole families together go out in
the country for several miles, and spend the
day wandering around and climbing mountains, and while occupied in the latter pursuit
quite a number fall and break their necks,
"which pastime," Mr. Renouf curiously remarked, "they enjoyed very much."
